sentence: The world's largest home improvement retailer, The Home Depot Inc. 's ( HD ) adjusted earnings of 65 cents per share for first-quarter 2012 climbed 30% from the prior-period earnings of 50 cents, primarily driven by solid comparable sales growth and strong operating performance.
Moreover, quarterly earnings were in line with the Zacks Consensus Estimate.
On a reported basis, including a benefit of 3 cents after the termination of Home Depot's guarantee of a senior secured loan, the company's quarterly earnings came in at 68 cents per share.
Moreover, the quarterly results were amplified by the increased number of centralized distribution centers and better merchandising tools.
Further, a mild winter season forced the spring demand to come forward, benefiting the quarter's performance.
During the reported quarter, net sales moved up 5.9% to $17,808 million compared with $16,823 million in the prior-year quarter.
The increase in net sales resulted from a growth of 5.8% in overall comparable store sales.
Comparable store sales in U.S. stores rose 6.1% during the first quarter.
However, net sales for the quarter fell short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $18,000 million.
During the quarter, gross profit increased 6.1% to $6,183 million from $5,828 million reported in the prior-year quarter.
Consequently, gross profit margin expanded by 10 basis points (bps) to 34.7%.
Operating profit during the quarter increased robustly by 20.5% to $1,714 million compared with $1,422 million in the year-ago period.
Operating margin expanded 110 bps to 9.6% compared with 8.5% in the prior-year quarter.
Improvement in operating margin was primarily driven by improved gross profit margin and effective cost management.
Home Depot ended its first-quarter 2012 with cash and cash equivalents of $3,191 million, long-term debt of $10,792 million and shareholder's equity of $17,975 million.

During the quarter, the company generated $2,490 million of cash from operations and deployed $1,131 million towards share buyback, $444 million for dividend payment, and $228 million as capital expenditures.

Following solid first-quarter results, management raised its fiscal 2012 earnings guidance to $2.90 per share, an increase of 17% from the previous fiscal's earnings of $2.47 and up from $2.79 forecasted earlier.
The current Zacks Consensus Estimate for fiscal 2012 stands at $2.91 per share, which is above the company's guidance.
Moreover, the company anticipates net sales to increase by 4.6%, up from 4% projected previously.
Home Depot is a leading player in the highly-fragmented home improvement industry.
The company has reinvigorated itself with a shift in focus from new square footage growth to maximization of productivity through its existing store base.
In addition, the company has implemented significant changes to its store operations to make them simpler and more customer-friendly.
We believe these initiatives will induce more customer traffic to its stores while boosting its top line.
Moreover, with the introduction of new warehousing and transportation system, the company has been able to improve its supply chain while minimizing cost.
Further, this has also facilitated Home Depot to improve its Central Automated Replenishment System for immediate refilling of stock while reducing its investment in inventory.
However, the company's business is highly competitive, primarily based on customer services, price, store location and assortment of merchandise.
The company faces stiff competition from local, regional and international players.
To maintain its market share, the company is making selective acquisitions and strategic alliances with third parties, which are increasing its operational risks.
Home Depot, which competes with Lowe's Companies Inc. ( LOW ), currently has a Zacks #2 Rank, implying a short-term 'Buy' rating.
Besides, the company retains a long-term 'Neutral' recommendation.
